title: Better inheritance and block overrides
body:
I'm not really sure I have an exact idea of the Jade implementation I want, but I do know the things I'm missing (or maybe just confused about implementing.) I would like to specify an alternative to layout.jade rather than forced into new folders for each wrapper. Also, I would like to have more control over blocks within layout.jade based on my view (ex: index.jade, user.jade, etc.) I've posted an example of the inheritance model I'm looking for as it would be written with django: ### shell.html ``` {% block title %}{% endblock %}MySite.com {% block css %}{% endblock %} {% block js %}{% endblock %}
{% block nav %}
    ...
{% endblock %}
{% block content %}{% endblock %}
``` ### user.html ``` {% extends "shell.html" %} {% block title %}{{ user.name }} - {% endblock %} {% block bodyClass %}user_page{% endblock %} {% block content %}

{{ user.name }}

... {% endblock %} ``` I'm not trying to overcomplicate jade's simplicity and certainly not turn it into django templating... but is a really readable and useful pattern (and certainly not unique to django: jsp tags, etc). Is there a way to do this with partials that isn't overly complicated? I can see partials working in the opposite direction (pointing the view at shell.jade and using user.jade as a partial), but calling user.jade seems more logical/readable from the controller and simply extending/overriding a wrapper. Any concerns with this concept? Would this be putting functionality in jade that should be elsewhere (as per jade's design)?
